content:
tudor mothers 152 males.
Collect embryos as early and late gastrula (3-5 after
eggs laid)
(Things to think about: Is staining exactly comparable
to that observed in the otherwise 152 stock.
Does the absence of pole cells affect the size or
morphology of the posterior midgut? What happens to the
cells that would have made germ cells, do they die or
become emdoderm?)
tudor mothers 89;05 males.
Collect embryos as late embryos (10-14 after eggs laid)
(Things to think about: Do gonads form without pole
cells, can the mesodermal components differentiate in
the absence of germ cells? How would you test whether a
failure to produce a 89.03 staining pattern reflects the
absence of germ cells or abnormalites in the
abdominally derived mesodermal precursors.)
concertina mothers 43.03 males.
Collect embryos as blastoderms, early gastrula late
gastrula(~3hrs after eggs laid.)
(Things to think about: Are stripes affected by the
mutant? What does the staining pattern in late embryos
tell us about the morphogenetic movements in concertina
derived embryos? Why should this remind you of the
experiments of Vogt (1929) on amphibian embryos
concertina mothers 152 males.
Collect embryos as early and late gastrula (3-5 after
eggs laid)
(Things to think about: Do the posterior cells stain
even though the do not form a posterior midgut? What
does this mean about the maternal effect of concertina?
Is it a morphiogen establishing the endodermal lineage?)
concertina mothers 39,05 males.
Collect embryos as late embryos (10-14 after eggs laid)
(Things to think about: Do gonads form in the absence of
a posterior midgut? The pole cells are normally
carried into the interior of the embryo by the
